metadata.titleEn: HiWATER：Dataset of flux observation matrix (No.6 eddy covariance system) of the MUlti-Scale Observation EXperiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces (2012)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from site No.6 eddy covariance system (EC) in the flux observation matrix from 28 May to 21 September, 2012. The site (100.35970° E, 38.87116° N) was located in a cropland (maize surface) in Yingke irrigation district, which is near Zhangye, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1562.97 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.6 m; the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.15 m.
Raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Edire post-processing software (University of Edinburgh, http://www.geos.ed.ac.uk/abs/research/micromet/EdiRe/), including spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. Moreover, the observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC), which was proposed by Foken and Wichura [1996]: class 1 (level 0: Δst<30 and ITC<30), class 2 (level 1: Δst<100 and ITC<100), and class 3 (level 2: Δst>100 and ITC>100), representing high-, medium-, and low-quality data, respectively. In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day; the missing data were replaced with -6999. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m^3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m^3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m^2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m^2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m^2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xlsx format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2016) (for multi-scale observation experiment or sites information), Xu et al. (2013) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Verification.Question: Are there challenges related to the effectiveness of temperature separation approaches in arid regions?

Disjunctive.Question: Which sensor network is primarily used in the oasis-desert observational setups: eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, or automatic meteorological stations?

What datasets were used to determine evapotranspiration ratios during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting multi-scale observational data in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced in collecting multi-scale observational data in eco-hydrological research is the limited availability of observations that can effectively capture the upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces, as addressed by the HiWATER experiment through a hierarchically nested instrumentation approach.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that supports eco-hydrological process studies in an oasis-desert environment?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that supports eco-hydrological process studies in an oasis-desert environment is the multiscale dataset from the HiWATER project, which includes data from eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing missions.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific attributes or characteristics of the flux observation matrix utilized in eco-hydrological studies within oasis-desert areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, soil moisture, leaf area index, vegetation dynamics

Feature Specification.Answer: errors from image classification, overestimation of canopy temperature, uncertainties from atmospheric upwelling radiation, uncertainties from transmittance

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'quality control' in the context of generating datasets from eco-hydrological experiments?
Definition.Answer: Quality control in the context of generating datasets from eco-hydrological experiments involves a thorough process of ensuring data accuracy and reliability. This includes sensor calibration, careful data collection, meticulous data processing, and the generation of datasets that are rigorously checked for quality before being made available for research and analysis.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method utilizing eddy covariance systems compare to the use of high-precision thermal infrared cameras in estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance (EC) system provides direct measurements of turbulent fluxes like sensible and latent heat at high frequencies (10 Hz), and is used for energy balance closure. High-precision thermal infrared cameras, on the other hand, measure soil and canopy component temperatures for input into models like TSEB to estimate E, T, and ET. The EC system is limited by energy balance closure issues and uncertainties in H estimation, while thermal cameras require accurate image classification and conversion to radiometric temperatures.

Interpretation.Question: How can the combination of stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques with eddy covariance measurements provide a more comprehensive understanding of evapotranspiration patterns in a heterogeneous landscape?
Interpretation.Answer: The combination of stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques with eddy covariance measurements allows for the validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates by providing observed ratios of these components. This approach helps overcome challenges in measuring individual components of evapotranspiration, especially in complex, heterogeneous landscapes.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological challenges might arise when using high-resolution thermal cameras to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures, and how can these challenges impact the accuracy of evapotranspiration models?
Interpretation.Answer: Methodological challenges when using high-resolution thermal cameras include image classification errors, which can lead to incorrect soil and canopy temperature estimates. These errors impact the accuracy of models like the TSEB model by affecting the calculated component temperatures, ultimately influencing the estimation of latent heat fluxes and evapotranspiration rates.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could multiscale datasets contribute to overcoming the challenges of observing eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes, and what types of instruments are essential for capturing these processes effectively?
Interpretation.Answer: Multiscale datasets can address the challenge of observing eco-hydrological processes by providing comprehensive data across different scales through hierarchically nested instrumentation. Essential instruments include eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing tools like LiDAR and thermal imagers, which collectively capture detailed eco-hydrological interactions in diverse landscapes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to incomplete energy balance closure in eddy covariance flux measurements, errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures, and a strong advective environment affecting the TSEB model performance. The uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference also plays a significant role in influencing the model's accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for multiscale observations in eco-hydrological process studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Multiscale observations are needed in eco-hydrological process studies because upscaling these processes on heterogeneous surfaces is challenging due to limited availability of multiscale data. HiWATER addresses this challenge by using hierarchically nested instrumentation to capture multiscale and multidisciplinary data, allowing for a better understanding of oasis-desert interactions and eco-hydrological dynamics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the main causes of errors in estimating component temperatures from thermal images in agricultural areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in estimating component temperatures from thermal images in agricultural areas are caused by image classification errors, particularly when classifying vegetation and soil pixels. These errors vary with vegetation abundance and lead to overestimation of canopy temperatures. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance, as well as uncertainties in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy, contribute to errors in temperature estimation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing multiscale observation techniques on the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimation in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing multiscale observation techniques can significantly improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimation in heterogeneous landscapes by providing detailed and diverse data that account for the variability in surface conditions. This approach, as seen in the HiWATER experiment, allows for a more comprehensive understanding of eco-hydrological processes by capturing data at different scales, from local to regional, thereby enhancing the reliability of models like the TSEB model in estimating evaporation and transpiration accurately.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific steps are involved in preprocessing the eddy covariance data to ensure its quality and reliability for flux estimation in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The preprocessing of eddy covariance data involves several steps including outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (double coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality evaluation of flux values is conducted based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics. Data is further filtered by removing erroneous instrument data, data within 1 hour before and after rainfall, data with more than 3% missing in 30-minute intervals, and weak turbulence data at night (u* less than 0.1 m/s).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration using remote sensing and ground-based observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration is achieved by integrating ground-based soil and canopy component temperatures with a high-resolution thermal camera into a two-source energy balance (TSEB) model. The Craig–Gordon model is applied to partition ET using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes. The soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes are estimated with the TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes are calculated through energy balance equations. The component temperatures are derived from thermal images, classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method, and validated against radiometric temperatures.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and observation techniques enable the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data over heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The instrumentation and observation techniques include a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Enablement.Question: How do ground-based measurements enable the accurate separation of soil and canopy component temperatures in a highly advective agricultural area?
Enablement.Answer: Ground-based measurements enable accurate separation by using soil and canopy component temperatures calculated from images obtained with a thermal camera. These temperatures are validated against surface radiometric temperatures calculated from long-wave radiation observations, ensuring reliable estimates of latent heat fluxes and separation of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration components.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for the effective use of a two-source energy balance model in estimating evapotranspiration over vegetated land?
Enablement.Answer: Effective use of a two-source energy balance model requires accurate measurements of soil and canopy component temperatures, reliable separation of these components, and validation with observed ratios of evaporation and transpiration using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes along with eddy covariance system measurements. The model's performance is influenced by the strong advective environment and potential errors in surface–air temperature differences.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are the current data collection methods for capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods, as described in the field above, utilize a hierarchical and nested scale approach with a combination of eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing technologies. This setup is designed to address the challenge of capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes, although the effectiveness can be hindered by poor availability of multiscale observations.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using thermal infrared cameras for soil and canopy temperature measurements in agricultural areas?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges include image classification errors that may arise from vegetation abundance, leading to misclassification of soil pixels as vegetation pixels. This results in overestimation of canopy temperature. There are also uncertainties related to atmospheric upwelling radiation, transmittance, and the incoming short- and long-wave radiation through the canopy, which can affect the accuracy of estimated temperatures.

Request/Directive.Question: Analyze the challenges faced in scaling eco-hydrological observations across heterogeneous surfaces and the methodologies used to address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: The primary challenge in scaling eco-hydrological observations is the limited availability of multiscale data. To address this, HiWATER implemented instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including a sparse network to capture oasis-desert interactions and a superstation within the oasis. Multiple EC towers and automatic meteorological stations were established across various landscapes. Intensive observation periods and remote sensing missions, using LiDAR and other technologies, were conducted to obtain comprehensive multiscale data. These measures facilitated the examination of eco-hydrological processes across scales.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the strategies used to ensure the quality control of datasets obtained from multiscale eco-hydrological experiments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Quality control strategies for datasets from multiscale eco-hydrological experiments include thorough sensor calibration, meticulous data collection, and rigorous data processing. Each dataset undergoes quality checks to ensure integrity and accuracy. Observations are collected through a combination of ground-based instrumentation, such as eddy covariance towers and meteorological stations, and airborne remote sensing, using technologies like LiDAR and thermal imaging. The datasets are then made freely available, ensuring transparency and accessibility for further research.
